Penrose limits
-----------------

The penrose limit is constructed as follows \cite{Penrose}:
starting with a solution of the Einstein equations, we zoom in on the neighborhood
of a null geodesic by choosing coordinates adapted to the it and then scaling
the metric by a constant factor in such a way that the neighborhood of the
null geodesic is expanded off to infinity. Taking advantage of the homogeneous
scaling of the lagrangian under this transformation, we see that any solutions
of the field equations remain solutions of the same equations after the limit.
.
This procedure always generates a plane-wave space-time which solves Einstein's
equations, and generically can have non-zero curvature.

The Weyl tensor of any plane-wave is either null or vanishes.

We present here a brief recapitulation of relevent earlier work on
non-linear sigma models and their renormalization.
In \cite{Curtright:1984dz, Braaten:is}, a simple geometrical interpretation was given
for the renormalization group flow in certain supersymmetric non-linear sigma models
where Wess-Zumino
\cite{Wess:yu,Witten:tx} terms are present.  These terms were interpreted as the
addition of torsion to the connection on the target manifold.
The renormalization flow can be interpreted as a geometrical deformation
of the target space manifold.  When Wess-Zumino terms are absent,
the geometric flow depends on the Riemannian curvature of the target
manifold \cite{Friedan:1980jf, Friedan:1980jm}.  
With the addition of Wess-Zumino terms, a similar interpretation
may be given, however, the curvature in this case is derived from a
connection with torsion.
In the case of Wess-Zumino-Witten models, where the target
space is a group manifold, the torsion is derived from the structure
constants of the Lie group \cite{Goldberg}.
The genralized connection with torsion
constructed in this manner may "flatten"
the manifold, i.e. cause the curvature to vanish.
In this case the manifold is said to be parallelized,
\cite{Cartan-Schouten,Einstein}
An interesting result of this parallelization is the existence of renormalization
group fixed points whose origin is given a geometrical interpretation.

The dynamics of the massless sector of string theory at low energy
is described by an effective theory taking the form of a supergravity
theory on the target space-time of the string $\sigma$-model.
Two approaches to establishing this effective action exist.
In the first approach \cite{Scherk:etal},
one may write the most general action reflecting the space-time
symmetries of the massless modes of the string theory.
Tree-level (in $g_s$) S-matrix computations are then performed in the string
theory, at some loop order in $\alpha^\prime$. The coefficients
appearing in the space-time effective action are then fixed by the
requirement that scattering at low energy in the two theories
coincide. Solutions of the equations of motion of for this effective theory
might display a perturbative nature in $\alpha^\prime$.
The second approach \cite{Weyl_inv} is to compute the renormalization group
$\beta$ functions (or Weyl anomaly ) for the couplings in the string $\sigma$-model.
The requirement of Weyl invariance of the string theory, in the
form of the vanishing of the $\beta$ function (again, to some order
in $\sigma$-model perturbation theory), then yields the
equations of motion which can then be used to construct the low-energy
supergravity effective action. The couplings of the worlsheet theory
appear as the fundamental fields in the supergravity action.

Metsaev and Tseytlin
\cite{Metsaev-Tseytlin} have demonstrated that parallelizable spaces
yield solutions of the string effective action
to order $(\alpha^{\prime})^{2}$, and have also shown that the
effective action can be recast in a form involving the curvature
derived from a generalized connection with the addition of torsion
(the so called "string torsion"),
arising from the sigma model Wess-Zumino antisymmetric coupling.
The two-loop correction to the $\beta$ function for a metric corresponding
to a parallelizable target space manifold is
shown to vanish in a particular renormalization scheme, and for a
deformation of the manifold in other renormalization schemes.
